did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Gwilym Davies Appalachian and Adirondack Mountains collection
1997-1998
did.physdesc: 9 sound recordings : digital audio files, WAV

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Gwilym Davies Appalachian and Adirondack Mountains collection was processed by Jesse Hocking.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Gwilym Davies Appalachian and Adirondack Mountains collection is open for research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Gwilym Davies Appalachian and Adirondack Mountains collection (AFC 2007/004), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Gwilym Davies (born 1946) is a collector of folk songs from Hampshire, England. He has recorded folk music in Hampshire, Gloucestershire, Devon, the United States and elsewhere and has deposited recordings with the British Library Sound Archive and the Library of Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Field recordings of songs and tales from Virginia, West Virginia, and New York State (Appalachian and Adirondack Mountains) made by Gwilym Davies in 1997 and 1998. Performers recorded include Spencer Moore of Chilhowie, VA; Phyllis Marks of Glenville, West Virginia in the company of Helena Triplett of Elkins, West Virginia; Rita Emerson of Glenville, West Virginia; Russell Lehew of Mannington, West Virginia; Dick Richards of Lake Luzerne, Saratoga, New York; Catherine Charron Labier of Whitehall, New York; Jim Cleveland and Colleen Cleveland of Brant Lake, New York.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Gwilym Davies Appalachian and Adirondack Mountains collection was recorded onto DAT tapes, each one containing multiple recording sessions or events. The DATS were digitized, and an audio file was created for each event. The finding aid arrangement reflects the events in chronological order. The digital id numbering, C742-69 through C742-77, are identifiers provided by the donor and are how the files are named. Descriptions, performer and song lists, and notes about performances used in the finding aid come directly from the donor's documentation.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

The finding aid arrangement reflects the events in chronological order. The digital id numbering, C742-69 through C742-77, are identifiers provided by the donor and are how the files are named. did.unittitle:
Catherine Charron Labier tells folktales, in Rexford, New York,
January 8, 1998

scopecontent.p: Catherine Charron Labier tells folktales learned from her grandfather Charrod and great-grandfather LaChapelle, who were born in Quebec. LaChapelle was a "boatman" (he had a fleet of Champlain Canal boats and hauled produce from the Champlain Valley to New York City), as was his son. Catherine's mother grew up on a canal boat. Lachapelle lived with Catherine's family in the French community of Whitehall, New York. Charron was a farmer in West Haven, Vermont, which is just across the Lake Champlain Sarrows from Whitehall, New York. Until she went to school Catherine Charron (Labier) spoke only French. These family tales have remained in oral tradition. Catherine is the first generation to tell them outside her family.

row.entry: Rene falls in love with Gabrielle, wants to marry her. Her father says that he must get Devil's three golden hairs. At first village, there is a dying apple tree, at second, the water is drying up, at the third. Ferryman tells him Devil lives in mountains. Ferryman wants to hand job in. Meets Devil's wife. Devil arrives, René hides. When he is asleep, she plucks a hair from him - Devil tells her that the dying tree has a nest of snakes under it. She plucks another hair. Devil tells her that beavers have blocked she river. She plucks another hair and he tells her that ferryman should leave next customer in the boat. Rene leaves and tells ferryman what to do, then tells villagers about the dam, and the next villagers about the snakes. They all give him sacks of gold - Devil is chasing him. He marries Rene. (Labier got the story from a 90-year-old French Canadian woman in Burlington, Vermont.
Fiddler. Plays for dance - see lights in wood. He gets the people inside and follows them and disappeared. But the wind is the Devil begging Rene to stop playing fiddle (family story).

John loves hunting. His mother is worried about the loup-garou. He keeps going to the woods - is meeting a red-headed girl there. He tries to persuade her to meet his parents before All-Souls Day. She changes into a fox - she is the loup-garou. He loses his soul. (family story)

André goes out to get wood. Meets a girl and they spend the day together. She chops all the day's wood with a magic spell. Next day the same thing happens but this time she chops 10 cords of wood by a spell. Next day the same. She helps André kill a deer. Next day she helps him shoot ten turkeys. She makes him get lost in the woods - she has changed to an old hag - it is the loup-garou. Now the sound of the wolf is André calling to his parents. (family story)

Thérèse is treated cruelly by her miserly father. He throws her out. She dies. He buries her in a poor coffin and buries her. One night there is a storm and a knocking on the door. He dies in storm. Neighbours find him dead on the bed. Thérèse's body had floated onto the bed. They give her a good burial but he is then buried out by the tree. (Cajun story)
Marguerite swims away with the whales. Marries a whale. Comes back a year later with a white offspring. This is how the Beluga whale became white. (family story)

did.unittitle:
Various people sing and tell stories at a social get-together at Riverview Orchards Rexford, New York,
January 18, 1998

row.entry: George Ward sings "Everyday Dirt" (Doc Watson version of Bill the Weaver - beginning missed)
Linda Crump (from Bought Corners, Saratoga Co) tells comic anecdote about her father
John Roberts (Brit living in the USA) sings "William Taylor" (Joseph Taylor version)

did.unittitle:
Various people sing and tell stories at a social get-together at Riverview Orchards Rexford, New York (continuation of C742-69),
January 18, 1998

row.entry: Susan Trump sings "The Angel Gabriel" (accompanying herself on lap dulcimer)
Vaughn Ward sings "Fourteen Ninety-Two" from Sara Cleveland repertoire. George Ward on guitar.
Catherine Labier tells story of "The Singing Bones" (Traditional tale from her Champlain Valley French Canadian background - folk tale of which there are European versions)
Kathleen Gill recites "Happy Birthday Mr. Moon"
Jamie Cleveland sings "My Bonny Bon Boy" (Lord Randall)
Al Bain sings "I'm my Own Grandpa"
Al and Kathy Bain sing "The Eastbound Train Was Crowded"
Vaughn Ward sings "Busk Busk Bonnie Lassie" (Bonny Glen Shee) (learned from Belle Stewart)
Linda Crump tells another anecdote about her father
Catherine Labier tells story of how the bears got into Canada
Ruth Olmstead of Rexford sings her mother's version of "The Fox" (incomplete)
Colleen and Jamie sing "The Heilan' Man" written by Matt McGinn from whom George Ward learned it in 1969. Jamie and Colleen learned it from George (George Vaughn sings last verse)
Catherine Labier tells tale of Devil and the Mirror (learned from her great-grandfather LaChappelle)
Vaughn sings "Call In and Out the Windows" (remembered from her childhood in the Southwest/traditional in Arkansas, Oklahoma, Eastern Texas)

"The Jam on Gerry's Rock" (2 verses only)
"The Little Mohee" (starts it by reading words, but it is not his version, so he then sings his version complete)
"Banks of Red Roses" (1 verse and a chorus)

row.entry: "I'm Dying for Someone to Love Me" (complete)

Jim sings "Three Men They Went a-Hunting"
Jim tells tall tale of being chased by coyotes
"What will the Birds Do, Mother, in the Spring" (complete)
Colleen sings "Before Daylight in the Morning"
Colleen sings "Every Rose grows Merry in Time" (James joins in chorus)
Colleen tells stories from her grandmother: "Catch it, Bottle it, Paint it Green" [bawdy]; "Tim and the Giant"; "Shiver and Shake" (another Tim story); "Mick and Pat" (cantefable)

did.unittitle:
Jim Cleveland and his daughter, Colleen Cleveland, sing songs at the house of Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland, Brant Lake, New York,
February 18, 1998

scopecontent.p: Jim Cleveland (age 74) and his daughter Colleen Cleveland (age 37) sing songs. Colleen's nephew James (age 17) also sings. Colleen learned her songs from her grandmother Sara Cleveland.

row.entry: Jim sings "The Handsome Cabin Boy" (forgets one verse, remembers it and completes the song - later he sang it straight through)
Colleen sings "Across the Blue Mountains" (verse 2 as in "High Germany")
Jim sings "The Butcher Boy" (last words missed)
